channel.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
channel.description:
Yo, found this script recently: https://github.com/Tompazi/confundo
What this script does is it replaces letters with similar looking Unicode glyphs. So you feed it a string, and it outputs several strings that look the same, yet use different characters.
An example that comes to mind: If your target is using a chat program that allows Unicode in user names, you might be able to impersonate an admin, some relative or a friend, and try to talk them into giving up info you're after.

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: ricksanchez
item.description:
I’m not that knowledgeable about this but it would be interesting to test which sites allow such “badly formatted” usernames for registration.
Is there an easy way to see who filters such stuff right away? Seems like some browsers already do it ? ( from what I read from @SmartOne )

Read full topic
item.source: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: SmartOne
item.description:
Thanks for your advise. It seems that I was really too stupid to customize the options However, it also seems that my browser auto-corrects some of the characters in a url. I can see it being useful with usernames and such

Read full topic
item.source: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: TheDoctor
item.description:
1.) Type in the text box the original username
2.) Now you can choose different characters (Radio buttons) for the letters (Focus on 'o’s; they can easily be changed )
3.) Copy the fake username at the bottom

Should work . Maybe you’ve forgot to change some of the letters before copying?

Read full topic
item.source: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: SmartOne
item.description:
Interesting website, but it doesn’t seem to work for me. It only gives out the original one. Already tried it on the 0x00sec registration form and it says ‘username already taken’. Must be doing something wrong…

Read full topic
item.source: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: TheDoctor
item.description:
Nope. When I tried to register pry0сс (Yes, that’s already the fake version; no chance to identify it ), it said only numbers, letters and underscores are allowed…

Read full topic

item.title: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
item.dc:creator: TheDoctor
item.description:
Ever wondered why so many sites don’t allow Unicode to be used in usernames? Yep, that’s the reason…

// Edit: A simple online converter: Homoglyph Attack

One example: Joe_Schmoe --> Jοe_Schmoe

Could you spot the difference?

Proof (SHA-256):

Original: bb1c1ec26ebae7df700719461ce0a0bc5aac1aac2fa11cc0a345c9512776e13c
Fake: 650c21d8405085c8e6f0469ed5c4e770ad50e0cb4231f603693b631fe8be3d7b

Read full topic
item.source: Confundo - abusing Unicode for fun and phishing
